neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.\n\nClimate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.\n\nYou can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.\n\nClimate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.\n\nYou can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.\n\nA year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.\n\nStay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‚Äòhaha‚Äô if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: It is boring. \n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‚Äòhaha‚Äô if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: Do you like football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: do you like football

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Which team do you watch?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: which team do you watch play

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I cannot match anything, the only thing I can watch is the World Cup on RTE Player.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: i know cant match any thing only thing i can watch is world cup on rte player

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Is he good?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: oh ok is he good?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I cannot watch football channels because I do not have access to them.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: no i cant watch football channels dont acess to them

Here is an example sentence written without any style: What health conditions do you have? I find it interesting when players execute impressive moves or make great saves. Besides that, I do not really like football.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: ok what health conditions do you have i find it interesting when players pull off cool moves or great saves beside that i dont really like football

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I do not really know, it gets boring sometimes, I guess.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: i dont really know it gets boring sometimes i guess

Here is an example sentence written without any style: That is unfortunate. Is it treatable?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: thats unfortunate is it treatable

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I agree that too much money is spent on players.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: i agrre too much money for players

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I have seen it before on TV, mess everywhere and constant noise.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: yeah ive seen it before on tv mess avrywhere and constant niose

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I have not decided yet. What about you?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: no not yet havent decided, you?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I noticed that as well.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: same i noticed that as wel

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. neutral_message:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‚Äòhaha‚Äô if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: How are you?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hi there, how are you?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Who do you support?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: So, who do you support?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I have never been interested in the game. None of my family members like it, so I was not influenced by it during my youth.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: It's a game I never got into. None of my family like it, so I never was influenced from a young age 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is also everywhere these days. I am sick of the country's obsession with it.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: It's also e verywhere these days. Sick of the country's obsession with it

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I love cricket and rugby union.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I do love cricket and rugby union

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Why do you like football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: So why do you like football?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: The money players earn is unfair.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Another thing, the money players earn is so unfair

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I agree about the passion. It is an emotional game.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Agree about thre passion. It's an emotioinal game

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Nurses deserve that kind of pay.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I know it's a tired argument, but nurses deserve that kind of pay!

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you support a team?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hey there. Do you support a team?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: What reasons do you have for liking football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Are there any reasons in particular that you like football?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I cannot think of many reasons.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Personally, I can't think of many reasons!

Here is an example sentence written without any style: One reason is the passion and drama that football can produce.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Perhaps one reason is for the passion and drama football can produce.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Good evening, Bouncy Dog. Do you have a favorite football team?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Evening, Bouncy Dog. So, is there a football team you like?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I do not understand the appeal of football.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I personally can't see the fuss with football

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I did not watch any. I rarely watch it, except perhaps the World Cup.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: No I didn't watch any. I very, very rarely watch it. World Cup perhaps

Here is an example sentence written without any style: You like football, but do not like any team, which is unusual.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: You like football, but don't like any team? That's unusual!

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I am aware of that. The World Cup is a global event, so I might watch one or two games.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Yes I know that. The World Cup is a global event so I may watch a game or two

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Football players are overpaid and have large egos.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Football players are over-paid people with huge egos

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is true. I feel uneasy knowing they earn in a week what I earn in ten years.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: That's very true. I jjust feel uneasy knowing they earn in a week what I earn in ten years!

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I agreed with a point you made.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I just agreed with a point yojummade

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I am not sure, not Bouncy Dog, I think.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Not sure...not Bouncy Dog, I think!

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Fluffy Cat was absent, so I cannot comment about them.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Fluffy Cat was AWOL, so can't comment about them

Here is an example sentence written without any style: The imposter is a panda.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Imposter is Panda


\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
